Question_1.Context: Fruit by-products contain valuable bioactive substances. Phenolic compounds are one of the bioactive substances found in fruit by-products.
Question_1.Question: What are phenolic compounds chemically characterized by?
Question_1.A: Aromatic and benzene ring with one or more hydroxide groups
Question_1.B: Aliphatic structure with multiple hydroxide groups
Question_1.Source: Chemically, molecular structures with an aromatic and benzene ring, as well as one or more hydroxide groups are called phenolic compounds; these compounds have derivatives with useful properties (glycosides, esters, methyl esters, etc.) (Barba et al. 2014).

Question_2.Context: Phenolic compounds are abundant in fruit and vegetable wastes. Different extraction methods can influence the total phenolic content in fruit by-products.
Question_2.Question: Which extraction method was found to be more efficient for extracting phenolic compounds from fruit by-products?
Question_2.Source: The pressurized hot-water extraction approach seemed to be more efficient than the organic solvent and enzyme-assisted extraction approach (Islam et al. 2021).

Question_3.Context: Phenolic compounds have antioxidant and antibacterial properties. Some specific phenolic compounds are frequently identified in different fruit by-products.
Question_3.Question: Which of the following is NOT a frequently identified phenolic compound in fruit by-products?
Question_3.Source: Among thousands of phenolic compounds, gallic acid, catechin, epicatechin, hydroxycinnamic acids, ferulic acid, quercetin, caffeic, procatechinic, syringic, vanillic acid, dopamine, hydroxy-tyrosol, tyrosol, cyanidin glycosides, L-dopa, p-coumaric acid, syringic acid, mangiferin, rutin, etc. are frequently identified in different FBPs.

Question_4.Context: Fruit by-products are rich in bioactive compounds. Phenolic compounds are found in significant amounts in various fruit by-products.
Question_4.Question: Which fruit by-product demonstrated the highest concentration of soluble phenolic compounds?
Question_4.Source: They found that rambutan peel had the highest concentration of soluble phenolic compounds (12.68 ± 0.76 g/100 g DM) compared to mango seed (8.95 ± 0.36 g/100 g DM).

Question_5.Context: Phenolic compounds in fruit by-products have antioxidant properties. These compounds can be used as food preservatives.
Question_5.Question: Which phenolic compound has potential antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties, and functions as a preservative and a skin protection agent?
Question_5.Source: For example, ferulic acid has potential antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties, it functions as a skin protection agent, a preservative, and a cross-linking agent.

Question_6.Context: Fruit by-products are a source of valuable bioactive substances. Phenolic compounds are considered nutraceuticals.
Question_6.Question: What is the characteristic of nutraceuticals?
Question_6.A: They are essential compounds in the human diet
Question_6.B: They are secondary metabolites found in plants
Question_6.D: They are exclusively found in animal products
Question_6.Source: Bioactive compounds are also signified as nutraceuticals which reflect their presence with biological significance in the human diet.

Question_7.Context: Fruit by-products contain bioactive substances with health benefits. Phenolic compounds are part of the bioactive substances found in fruit by-products.
Question_7.Question: What functions do phenolic compounds exhibit in plants?
Question_7.Source: For instance, due to their bitterness and astringency they safeguard fruits and vegetables from early eating, attract insects and birds due to their attractive color formation.

Question_8.Context: Fruit by-products are rich in bioactive compounds. Phenolic compounds are abundant in fruit and vegetable wastes.
Question_8.Question: What is the chemical characteristic of phenolic compounds?
Question_8.B: Have a cyclic structure with nitrogen groups
Question_8.C: Include aromatic and benzene rings with hydroxide groups
Question_8.Source: Chemically, molecular structures with an aromatic and benzene ring, as well as one or more hydroxide groups are called phenolic compounds.

Question_9.Context: Phenolic compounds in fruit by-products have antioxidant properties. These compounds can be used as food preservatives.
Question_9.Question: Which phenolic compound is known for its potential antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties?
Question_9.Source: There have been claims that quercetin offers positive health.

Question_10.Context: Fruit by-products contain bioactive substances with health benefits. Phenolic compounds are part of the bioactive substances found in fruit by-products.
Question_10.Question: Which extraction method was found to be more efficient for extracting phenolic compounds from fruit by-products?
Question_10.Source: The pressurized hot-water extraction approach seemed to be more efficient than the organic solvent and enzyme-assisted extraction approach.
